list.title: Question 1
list.content:
The diagram below shows a car of massmmmdescending a slope. The car, initially at rest, covers a distance of 27 m in 3.0 s.

![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/5b5634a7-bfb0-4c45-859f-2684b781580b/images/3d546597-f800-49ad-b760-e4ace00a2c04/PH0123.png)

The magnitude of the acceleration is given byA.\hspace{1em}3.0 m s−2^{-2}−2B.\hspace{1em}6.0 m s−2^{-2}−2C.\hspace{1em}9.0 m s−2^{-2}−2D.\hspace{1em}81 m s−2^{-2}−2
list.markScheme: BExplanation‾\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}Explanation​:From the equation of motions=ut+12at2s = ut + \dfrac{1}{2} at^2s=ut+21​at2initially the velocity,uuuis zero givinga=2 st2a = \dfrac{\textrm{2 s}}{t^2} \hspace{1em}a=t22 s​Substitutingt=3t = 3t=3s:a=(2)(27.0 m)(3.0s)2=6.0a=\dfrac{\textrm{(2)(27.0 m)}}{(3.0\ \ce{s})^2} = 6.0a=(3.0s)2(2)(27.0 m)​=6.0m s−2^{-2}−2

list.title: Question 2
list.content: An object moves at constant velocity for a period of time, after which it undergoes uniform deceleration until it comes to rest. A velocity-time graph is plotted for this motion. On the graph, which of the following would represent the displacement of the object?A.\hspace{1em}Gradient of the line connecting the initial and final velocities.B.\hspace{1em}x-interceptC.\hspace{1em}y-interceptD.\hspace{1em}Area under the graph
list.markScheme: DExplanation‾\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}Explanation​:For option A, the gradient of the line connecting the starting and ending velocities gives the average acceleration.For option B, x-intercept represents the time of when velocity is zero, therefore is incorrect.For option C, y-intercept represents the velocity when the time is zero, therefore is incorrect.For option D, area under the graph is the displacement, which is the correct answer.

list.title: Question 3
list.content: A ball rolls horizontally off the edge of the top of a cliff. It hits the ground at a distance 2.0 m horizontally away from the base of the cliff with a vertical speed of 20 m s−1^{-1}−1. What is the height of the cliff?A.\hspace{1em}20 mB.\hspace{1em}40 mC.\hspace{1em}60 mD.\hspace{1em}80 m
list.markScheme: AExplanation‾\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}Explanation​:Only the vertical motion needs to be considered here.v2=u2+2asv^2=u^2+2asv2=u2+2asThere is initially no vertical velocity sou=0u=0u=0v2=2gsv^2=2gsv2=2gs202=(2)(10)(s)20^2 = (2)(10)(s)202=(2)(10)(s)s=400(2)(10)s = \dfrac{400}{(2)(10)}s=(2)(10)400​s=20s = 20s=20mNote that for multiple choice questions it is normally appropriate to use 10 m s−2^{-2}−2as the acceleration of freefall.

list.title: Question 4
list.content: A basketball is launched at an angle and undergoes projectile motion. Air resistance is negligible. Which of the following is correct for the direction of its velocity vector and its acceleration vector at the highest point of its trajectory?Direction of velocity vectorDirection of acceleration vector\hspace{1.5em}A.\hspace{1.5em}horizontalno acceleration\hspace{1.5em}B.\hspace{1.5em}no velocityno acceleration\hspace{1.5em}C.\hspace{1.5em}no velocitydownward\hspace{1.5em}D.\hspace{1.5em}horizontaldownward
list.markScheme: DExplanation‾\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}Explanation​:At the top of its trajectory, vertical velocity will be zero, but the horizontal component of the velocity will maintain the same value throughout the motion, therefore velocity will be horizontal.Acceleration due to gravity is always acting and acts downward.

list.title: Question 6
list.content: A coin is tossed vertically upwards from an original height of1.51.51.5m above the ground. What is the maximum height reachedabove the groundif the coin was projected with an initial velocity of 3.0 m s−1^{-1}−1?  (Takeg=10g=10g=10m s−2^{-2}−2)A.0.45\hspace{1em} 0.450.45mB.1.50\hspace{1em} 1.501.50mC.1.95\hspace{1em} 1.951.95mD.6.00\hspace{1em} 6.006.00m
list.markScheme:
CExplanation‾\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}Explanation​:Solution 1:Maximum height occurs when the final speedvvvis zero. The height reached above hands=v2−u22as=0−9−20=0.45m\begin{aligned}
\ s &= \dfrac{v^2 - u^2}{2a}\\
\ s&=\dfrac{0-9}{-20} \\
\ &= 0.45\textrm{ m}\\
\end{aligned}ss​=2av2−u2​=−200−9​=0.45m​To find maximum height above the ground,0.450.450.45m+1.5+\ 1.5+1.5m = 1.95 mSolution 2:Using conservation of energy, kinetic energy is converted completely into gravitational potential energy at the top of the motion12mv2=mgh\dfrac{1}{2} mv^2 = mgh21​mv2=mgh12(3)2=10h\dfrac{1}{2} (3)^2 = 10h21​(3)2=10hh=0.45h=0.45h=0.45mTo find maximum height above the ground,0.450.450.45m+1.5+\ 1.5+1.5m = 1.95 m

list.title: Question 7
list.content: The take off speed of a passenger aircraft is 75.0 m s−1^{-1}−1. A plane starts from rest and accelerates at a steady rate of 1.25 m s−2^{-2}−2. Which of the following correctly states the minimum duration of the acceleration, and the minimum length of the runway needed for the take off?Duration of accelerationLength of the runway\hspace{1.5em}A.\hspace{1.5em}75.0m s−11.25m s−2\dfrac{75.0\textrm{ m s}^{-1}}{1.25\textrm{ m s}^{-2}}1.25m s−275.0m s−1​(75.0m s−1)2(2)(1.25m s−2)\dfrac{(75.0\textrm{ m s}^{-1})^2}{(2)(1.25\textrm{ m s}^{-2})}(2)(1.25m s−2)(75.0m s−1)2​\hspace{1.5em}B.\hspace{1.5em}75.0m s−11.25m s−2\dfrac{75.0\textrm{ m s}^{-1}}{1.25\textrm{ m s}^{-2}}1.25m s−275.0m s−1​(75.0m s−1)21.25m s−2\dfrac{(75.0\textrm{ m s}^{-1})^2}{1.25\textrm{ m s}^{-2}}1.25m s−2(75.0m s−1)2​\hspace{1.5em}C.\hspace{1.5em}(75.0m s−1)2(2)(1.25m s−2)\dfrac{(75.0\textrm{ m s}^{-1})^2}{(2)(1.25\textrm{ m s}^{-2})}(2)(1.25m s−2)(75.0m s−1)2​75.0m s−11.25m s−2\dfrac{75.0\textrm{ m s}^{-1}}{1.25\textrm{ m s}^{-2}}1.25m s−275.0m s−1​\hspace{1.5em}D.\hspace{1.5em}(75.0m s−1)2(2)(1.25m s−2)\dfrac{(75.0\textrm{ m s}^{-1})^2}{(2)(1.25\textrm{ m s}^{-2})}(2)(1.25m s−2)(75.0m s−1)2​(75.0m s−1)2(2)(1.25m s−2)\dfrac{(75.0\textrm{ m s}^{-1})^2}{(2)(1.25\textrm{ m s}^{-2})}(2)(1.25m s−2)(75.0m s−1)2​
list.markScheme: AExplanation‾\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}Explanation​:a=v−uta = \dfrac{v-u}{t}a=tv−u​⇒t=v−ua=75.0m s−1−01.25m s−2=75.0m s−11.25m s−2\hspace{2em} \Rightarrow t = \dfrac{v-u}{a} = \dfrac{75.0\textrm{ m s}^{-1}-0}{1.25\textrm{ m s}^{-2}} = \dfrac{75.0\textrm{ m s}^{-1}}{1.25\textrm{ m s}^{-2}}⇒t=av−u​=1.25m s−275.0m s−1−0​=1.25m s−275.0m s−1​v2=u2+2asv^2 = u^2 + 2asv2=u2+2as⇒s=v2−u22a=(75.0m s−1)2−022(1.25m s−2)=(75.0m s−1)22(1.25m s−2)\hspace{2em} \Rightarrow s = \dfrac{v^2-u^2}{2a} = \dfrac{(75.0\textrm{ m s}^{-1})^2-0^2}{2(1.25\textrm{ m s}^{-2})} = \dfrac{(75.0\textrm{ m s}^{-1})^2}{2(1.25\textrm{ m s}^{-2})}⇒s=2av2−u2​=2(1.25m s−2)(75.0m s−1)2−02​=2(1.25m s−2)(75.0m s−1)2​

list.title: Question 8
list.content:
The diagram shows the path of a football kicked from the ground.

![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/77913ebb-9bae-4e51-930d-46be726c3b93/images/38a80183-388d-4a4e-ba55-7b1ef3d0ed2c/Screenshot%202025-03-24%20at%205.29.42%E2%80%AFPM.JPEG)

Air resistance is negligible. Which of the arrowsAAA,BBB,CCC, orDDDrepresent the direction of the acceleration of the ball at the instant in time shown?
list.markScheme: CExplanation‾\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}Explanation​:In the absence of air resistance, gravity is the only force acting on the object so its acceleration acts downwards towards the centre of the Earth.The vertical velocity of the ball is decreasing whilst its horizontal velocity remains the same.

list.title: Question 9
list.content:
The graph shows the variation with timetttof the velocityvvvof a car traveling along a straight and level road.

![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/8fe007ab-df26-45df-b753-411208960677/images/9e41ef7e-8f69-4c96-baf0-46f791334376/Screenshot%202025-06-05%20at%208.45.48%E2%80%AFAM.png)

What time does it take for the car to travel a distance of 31.5 m fromttt= 0?A.\hspace{1em}2 sB.\hspace{1em}7 sC.\hspace{1em}10 sD.\hspace{1em}12 s
list.markScheme:
BExplanation‾\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}Explanation​:Displacement is the area under the graph of velocity-time. Breaking the shape into several areas up to time 7 s:

![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/8fe007ab-df26-45df-b753-411208960677/images/fd1b15a0-72ef-4bd7-b637-42b0a9e93f11/Screenshot%202025-06-05%20at%208.59.10%E2%80%AFAM.png)

Area =12(2)(4)+(5)(4)+12(5)(3)=31.5\dfrac{1}{2}(2)(4) + (5)(4) + \dfrac{1}{2}(5)(3) = 31.521​(2)(4)+(5)(4)+21​(5)(3)=31.5m

list.title: Question 10
list.content:
The graph shows the variation of velocityvvvwith timetttof a car.

list.title: Question 14
list.content:
The graph below shows how the acceleration of an objectaaavaries with timettt.

![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/2ac6b76d-2709-453b-9a01-dd8e09fc7d9c/images/225978ea-87fb-406a-9dc7-0b898236dcf3/Screenshot%202025-06-30%20at%205.16.39%E2%80%AFPM.png)

What is the change in speed of the object?A.\hspace{1em}7.07.07.0m s−1^{-1}−1B.\hspace{1em}28.028.028.0m s−1^{-1}−1C.\hspace{1em}42.042.042.0m s−1^{-1}−1D.\hspace{1em}56.056.056.0m s−1^{-1}−1
list.markScheme:
CExplanation‾\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}Explanation​:Change in speed is the magnitude of the area under an acceleration-time graph.To find the area under the graph we can split it into two sections.

![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/2ac6b76d-2709-453b-9a01-dd8e09fc7d9c/images/7a3ccd6a-bb00-4cc1-bb74-81d58abd51b8/Screenshot%202025-06-30%20at%205.17.41%E2%80%AFPM.png)

Section 1 is a rectangle. Area=(4)(7)=28=(4)(7)=28=(4)(7)=28m s−1^{-1}−1Section 2 is a triangle. Area=12(4)(7)=14= \dfrac{1}{2}(4)(7)=14=21​(4)(7)=14m s−1^{-1}−1Total area=28+14=42= 28+14=42=28+14=42m s−1^{-1}−1Alternative solution‾\underline{\textrm{Alternative solution}}Alternative solution​This can also be done in one step using the area of a trapeziumA=12(8+4)(7)=42A=\dfrac{1}{2}(8+4)(7)=42A=21​(8+4)(7)=42m s−1^{-1}−1

list.title: Question 15
list.content:
Define distance.[1]An object moves in a straight line on a level road. The variation of the object's distancedwith timetis shown on the graph below.

![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/2ad709bc-247a-45b1-a942-664f5d258dce/images/ec0aad4a-2afd-42a6-8ebe-1a8af181242f/Screenshot%202025-07-02%20at%202.47.38%E2%80%AFPM.JPEG)

Describe the motion of the object betweent=0.5t=0.5t=0.5s andt=1.0t=1.0t=1.0s.[1]Calculate the instantaneous speed of the object att=0.5t=0.5t=0.5s.[2]On the axes below, sketch a possible graph of the variation of velocityvvvof the object with timettt. There is no need to add values to the axes.[2]

![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/2ad709bc-247a-45b1-a942-664f5d258dce/images/c787d9d0-d867-4d03-980d-27f4c5fbad95/Screenshot%202025-07-02%20at%202.50.32%E2%80%AFPM.png)

Determine the direction of the change in momentum of the object during the motion.[2]
list.markScheme:
Length of the path followed✓\checkmark✓Slows down/decelerates✓\checkmark✓Further Explanation‾\underline{\textrm{Further Explanation}}Further Explanation​:The slope of the graph gives the speed of the object. The slope decreases betweent=0.5t=0.5t=0.5s andt=1.0t=1.0t=1.0s. Therefore the object slows down.Any evidence for drawing tangent att=0.5st=0.5\, st=0.5s✓\checkmark✓≪28−101−0=≫18±2ms−1\ll\dfrac{28-10}{1-0}=\gg18\pm2\, m\,s^{-1}≪1−028−10​=≫18±2ms−1✓\checkmark✓Further Explanation‾\underline{\textrm{Further Explanation}}Further Explanation​:The gradient of the graph at the time of interest gives the instantaneous speed of the object. To find the gradient, the tangent line should be drawn.

![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/2ad709bc-247a-45b1-a942-664f5d258dce/images/db214a2c-2e68-4bce-8a9a-e0cd2cc8719c/Screenshoot%202025-07-02%20at%202.52.52%E2%80%AFPM.JPEG)

The gradient of the tangent line =28−101−0=18\dfrac{28-10}{1-0}=181−028−10​=18m s−1^{-1}−1A straight or a curved line with a negative gradient✓\checkmark✓Starts from the y-intercept and ends up at the x-axis✓\checkmark✓

![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/2ad709bc-247a-45b1-a942-664f5d258dce/images/4ba5e265-a440-45f1-81d9-62bf89b670e0/Screenshot%202025-06-02%20at%2011.30.12%E2%80%AFAM.png)

Further Explanation‾\underline{\textrm{Further Explanation}}Further Explanation​:The gradient of the distance-time graph indicates the speed of the object. In one-dimensional motion, speed and velocity have the same magnitude. Since the gradient gets a smaller value with time and ends up with a zero value, velocity gets smaller and be zero at the end.The exact mathematical shape of the distance-time curve is not known, therefore it is not possible to determine the exact shape of the velocity-time graph. A linear graph has been included here, but curvature in the graph is permitted.The final momentum is less than the initial momentum✓\checkmark✓Opposite to the motion/backwards/negative✓\checkmark✓Further Explanation‾\underline{\textrm{Further Explanation}}Further Explanation​:The velocity of the object decreases. Therefore, the final momentumpfp_fpf​is less than the initialpip_ipi​momentum. The change in momentumΔp\Delta pΔp;Δp=pf−pi\Delta p=p_f-p_iΔp=pf​−pi​sincepip_ipi​>pfp_fpf​, the result should be negative which indicates the direction of the change in momentum is opposite to the motion of the object.

list.title: Question 16
list.content: A projectile is fired at an angle above the horizontal on the surface of Moon. Which of the following statements is correct about its motion:A.\hspace{1em}The magnitude of the horizontal component of its velocity remains unchanged until it falls on the surface of the moon.B.\hspace{1em}The magnitude of the vertical component of its velocity remains unchanged until it falls on the surface of the moon.C.\hspace{1em}The magnitude of the horizontal component of its velocity decreases steadily until it falls on the surface of the moon.D.\hspace{1em}The magnitude of the vertical component of its velocity decreases steadily until it falls on the surface of the moon.
list.markScheme: AExplanation‾\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}Explanation​:The moon has no atmosphere. As there is no air drag, there's no change in the horizontal component of velocity. It does not decrease (making option C incorrect, and option A correct).The magnitude of vertical component decreases only while the projectile moves upwards. At its maximum height, the vertical component becomes zero and then starts increasing in the in the downward direction until it hits ground (making D incorrect).Option B is obviously incorrect as moon's gravitation keeps changing the vertical component.

list.title: Question 17
list.content: A football player kicks a ball initially at rest. The ball reaches a speed of 36 km h−1^{-1}−1in a time of 0.5 s. Which of the following is the acceleration of the ball in terms of the gravitational acceleration,ggg?A.\hspace{1em}0.2gggB.\hspace{1em}0.5gggC.\hspace{1em}2gggD.\hspace{1em}7ggg

list.title: Question 19
list.content:
A cargo container is released from an airplane. A parachute is opened remotely a few seconds later to land it safely. Which graph shows the variation of the vertical accelerationaaawith timetttfor the cargo container from when it leaves the plane until landing?A.B.

![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/45391756-7a52-4e80-90d4-2492905455f9/images/008093a4-5c1e-419d-865d-2fad91185b6a/Screenshot%202025-05-27%20at%202.15.24%E2%80%AFPM.JPEG)



![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/45391756-7a52-4e80-90d4-2492905455f9/images/b3a16c1d-d1dc-48dd-832f-9535acc8b644/Screenshot%202025-05-27%20at%202.15.44%E2%80%AFPM.JPEG)

C.D.

![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/45391756-7a52-4e80-90d4-2492905455f9/images/e5911411-0db3-4109-bfcf-712ac30be345/Screenshot%202025-05-27%20at%202.15.50%E2%80%AFPM.JPEG)



![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/45391756-7a52-4e80-90d4-2492905455f9/images/3bf1ed62-d84b-4b48-a897-cdec1945761d/Screenshot%202025-05-27%20at%202.15.56%E2%80%AFPM.JPEG)
list.markScheme: DExplanation‾\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}Explanation​:The cargo starts with large negative (downward) acceleration. As the cargo container falls, it is speeding up; as it is speeding up, drag force increases, so the acceleration decreases until the cargo container reaches a terminal speed where acceleration is zero. After the parachute is opened, drag force will increase, which is greater than the weight of the cargo container, causing an opposite, upwards, acceleration (deceleration). As the cargo container slows down the drag force decreases, so the net force decreases, and acceleration decreases again until the cargo container reaches a lower terminal speed where acceleration is zero and the forces are balanced.

list.title: Question 28
list.content: An object is thrown vertically upwards at the edge of a cliff at heighthhhabove the ground. When the object passes the edge of the cliff while falling downwards, a second, identical object is released from rest. Air resistance is negligible. What increases for the second object as the two objects fall?A.\hspace{1em}AccelerationB.\hspace{1em}Distance from the groundC.\hspace{1em}Velocity relative to the object released earlierD.\hspace{1em}Distance from the object released earlier
list.markScheme: DExplanation‾\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}Explanation​:For options A & C, the accelerations of both objects are gravitational acceleration and constant, therefore the velocity difference is constant and both options are incorrect.For option B, the object released later was released from rest and so the distance from the ground decreases. Therefore, B is incorrect.For option D, the relative velocity of the two objects is constant because the acceleration for both objects is the same, therefore the distance between the two objects will increase and it is the correct option. In other words, the first object will always be moving faster than the second object, so the distance between them will increase.

list.title: Question 36
list.content:
The graph shows the variation of speedvvvof a ball with timettt.

![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/13b5c41f-9e6b-4937-8397-65c5b2d2336e/images/5281444d-ae8d-4868-83f7-f80dd8085194/Screenshot%202025-05-29%20at%201.10.05%E2%80%AFPM.png)

The initial speed of the ball is very high. Which of the following statements could be true for the ball?A. It is thrown vertically upward in the presence of air resistance.B. It is thrown vertically upward in the absence of air resistance.C. It is thrown vertically downward in the presence of air resistance.D. It is thrown vertically downward in the absence of air resistance.
list.markScheme: CExplanation‾\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}Explanation​:According to the graph, the ball has a decreasing deceleration and reaches terminal velocity. Since the acceleration of the ball is not constant, air resistance must be acting on the ball. Air resistance always acts in the direction opposite to the velocity.In an upward motion, air friction and gravity are in the same direction. Therefore, it is not possible for them to cancel each other so that the ball reaches terminal velocity. It should be moving in the downward direction. Hence, the answer is C.

In this case, the ball is falling so the direction of the displacement is downwards.Reference to use of the gradient of the graph to find instantaneous acceleration.✓\checkmark✓2.8±0.52.8\ \pm\ 0.52.8±0.5≪m s−2≫\ll\textrm{m s}^{-2}\gg≪m s−2≫✓\checkmark✓Further Explanation‾\underline{\textrm{Further Explanation}}Further Explanation​:The gradient of the graph at a given time gives the instantaneous acceleration of the car. list.markScheme: CExplanation‾\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}Explanation​:The velocity-time graph shows that the car moves in the positive direction for half of the time, and then in the negative direction for the second half of the motion. The gradient of a displacement-time graph at any point is the velocity. Therefore, the displacement-time graph that matches this motion will have a positive gradient for the first half of the motion and a negative gradient for the second half of the motion. The only graph correctly shows this is C.

list.title: Question 43
list.content:
A stone is thrown vertically upward in the presence of air resistance. Which of the following graphs best shows the variation of velocityvvvof the stone with timetttuntil it reaches the maximum height above the ground?A.B.

![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/07795333-081c-45d6-a535-7d81fe684558/images/1372cf34-9ff4-41eb-8e1b-409b309a48d5/PH0533aa.png)



![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/07795333-081c-45d6-a535-7d81fe684558/images/7a0b7787-0fec-4f49-8e31-29ea318dae6d/PH0533bb.png)

\hspace{1em}C.D.

![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/07795333-081c-45d6-a535-7d81fe684558/images/42a7ebb7-983c-4564-8c3c-7e51b7981ded/PH0533cc.png)



![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/07795333-081c-45d6-a535-7d81fe684558/images/f92baaf5-5218-4036-bc1c-47f423955d9d/PH0533dd.png)
list.markScheme: CExplanation‾\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}Explanation​:While the stone is ascending, its speed decreases due to gravitational attraction and air resistance. Although gravitational attraction is constant, air resistance decreases with speed. Therefore, the total force opposing the motion decreases. This results in a decrease in deceleration.When the acceleration decreases, the change in velocity gets lower for a constant change in time. Thus the gradient should decrease. Additionally, the velocity of the stone must be zero when it reaches maximum height. These two conditions are satisfied in choice C.
